body.p:
Dear Sir, Having the pleasure of being already introduced
to you—occasionally, when for two years ago I presented you
my little work, styled: Polyglott Porkesbook? in 6 different languages—
you will pardon me for the liberty I take now by forwarding to you
some sheets of a new work, which since my reentering upon
the duty of ministry here, in Wilkes Barre, has taken up my hours
of leisure. It is this a translation of D. Ottensoser's
work, called
Hebrew
into the English. The merit of this work is mainly:

list.item:
its being based upon the best Historians of ours,
as the authors of the books Hebrew, Josephus, u.s.f.

its adopting the pious principle, that the traditions of
our forfathers must be for us a law; they must not
depart from our mouth and from the mouth of our children
from henceforth and for evermore.

The author never neglects to point out in especial notes
the souces, out of which his statements are depickted;

its completeness. The author sought never to overlook
any important fact, and to relate in a noble and powerful

body.p:
style without to weary the curiosity of the reader with
useless triflings, and 5. its cheapness.—$2.00 for the whole—

I am of opinion, that a History of our people, managed
under such aspects and written in the Vernacular cannot
but prove great utility both to families and schools.
But even to scholars of profession a work of that kind
must open a wide field for investigations inasmuch as
it differs from other Historians and as it offers an acquaintance
with a large part of jewish Literature.

As far as my small ability goes I did all I could
to render the author's ideas faithfully and to give a correct
transcript of the original, though many notes and explanations
are anexed? which I thought proper to insert.

Now from the above motivs, and—if you like—to
overread the inclosed few sheets you, a most competent
judge easily can decide, whether a work of that kind
will meet the taste and favor of the public or not.
Have no regard whatever for myself if you find fault
with that what now is subject to your judgment, and
favor me with your opinion about it. IN case,
that the proof should meet your aprobation and you were of
opinion, that the public likewise may welcome it, then I
again will enter upon the purifying and conclusion of the
work. Meanwhile you would oblige me very much if you
were pleased to insert the anexed Call in the next
numbers of your high esteemed „Occident” accompanied by

a few words of recommendation and to induce your agents
to receive subscriptions. Of course, in order that the public
may be able to form an idea of that what there may to be
expected it becomes necessary to have a specimen before
their eyes. One or two chapters of the work inserted in your
esteemed Periodical would answer the purpose—if you
like to do so.—

Please and send me up the following months of the
„Occident” of this year, [inclosed you will receive the amount for],
and so I am in possession of the ten volumes of the above
Periodical, but most of them being not complete, you will show me
another great favor by forwarding to me those numbers, which
I am lacking, to a moderate price. Viz:
of Vol. I, year 1843, the numbers....2.3.4.6
The following volumes till presently are complete.
